body:
You're on an amazing killstreak.  You destroy everyone in your path, and you've taken down two out ouf four monuments--single handedly.  Then, that one person to whom you weren't paying enough attention to notice that they were coming up behind you hits you once, and you fly off the map.

    F*CK

you scream in the chat.

Why did you do it?
I don't want this thread to be a discussion about whether swearing is acceptable or unacceptable; we've already all shared our opinions about that in various other threads.  I want to know the answer to one simple question:  why?  Explain your reasoning below.
body_tagged:
You're on an amazing killstreak.  You destroy everyone in your path, and you've taken down two out ouf four monuments--single handedly.  Then, that one person to whom you weren't paying enough attention to notice that they were coming up behind you hits you once, and you fly off the map.

    F*CK

you scream in the chat.

Why did you do it?
I don't want this thread to be a discussion about whether swearing is acceptable or unacceptable; we've already all shared our opinions about that in various other threads.  I want to know the answer to one simple question:  why?  Explain your reasoning below.
title: Swearing - Why?

dude amazing tale warmed my heart.


but you know it's because those little kids can't hold their temper and they just go ham in chat to feel better about themselves. when Im frustrated I usually smash things like my keyboard, my nintendo DS, my dads windshield, etc.

replies.body: i honestly dont know why. i do occasionally swear, if it's the situation you're talking about its cause i knew i was super close and if i dont swear i just get disappointed irl for a couple minutes, but when i swear it kinda relieves that. i think its worth it. i try not to swear at people, but if you look at my infractions list you can see i have. but 99% of those infractions are because someone was being homophobic, sexist, racist etc or just being rly rude in the first place.

replies.body:
It's sort of a reflex to get anger out. 

On a side note, someone did a study in which two groups of people were too keep their hands in a bowl of freezing water for as long as they could. One group was told to remain silent and the other was told they could swear as much as they wanted. On average the swearing group was able to last twice as long with hands in the water as the silent group. This isn't related, I just wanted to share it.
replies.body_tagged:
It's sort of a reflex to get anger out. 

On a side note, someone did a study in which two groups of people were too keep their hands in a bowl of freezing water for as long as they could. One group was told to remain silent and the other was told they could swear as much as they wanted. On average the swearing group was able to last twice as long with hands in the water as the silent group. This isn't related, I just wanted to share it.

replies.body: It's been proven that swearing is a much more passionate form of language to us. Swearing even comes from a completely different part of your brain than normal speech, and so we don't really think of them as words that mean something, only an explanation. We've been taught throughout our lives that these words are bad, and so we often attribute them to bad experiences or feelings. Getting hit out of the world while on a kill streak triggers that in people, and causes them to swear.
replies.body_tagged: It's been proven that swearing is a much more passionate form of language to us. Swearing even comes from a completely different part of your brain than normal speech, and so we don't really think of them as words that mean something, only an explanation. We've been taught throughout our lives that these words are bad, and so we often attribute them to bad experiences or feelings. Getting hit out of the world while on a kill streak triggers that in people, and causes them to swear.

replies.body: Honestly, screaming vulgarities in chat isn't going to help you get back and turn back the clock where you can avoid being killed. Just hold it in yourself, don't scream in chat, that way things will be better ;)

replies.body: all in all though, i really need to stress that the rule shouldnt be so black and white- in many cases, swearing is acceptable, and in some it is harmful and annoying. there are so many variables that come into account. the players doing the swearing, the context, and (very importantly) the biases of the staff dealing out the punishments (yes, you have biases when dealing out punishments whether you like it or not, concious or subconciously) it really should be on a case by case basis, a black and white no swearing rule doesnt help. (sorry, i know this wasnt the intention of the thread but i had to add my final opinion)
replies.body_tagged: all in all though, i really need to stress that the rule shouldnt be so black and white- in many cases, swearing is acceptable, and in some it is harmful and annoying. there are so many variables that come into account. the players doing the swearing, the context, and (very importantly) the biases of the staff dealing out the punishments (yes, you have biases when dealing out punishments whether you like it or not, concious or subconciously) it really should be on a case by case basis, a black and white no swearing rule doesnt help.
